page.title: 16WOODLANDS DOWNLAND MINAL
page.content: The planted woodland consists mainly of windbreaks, which are largely beech, but there ia a coniferous one in an exposed hill-top position. New planting in the hedgerows is English ash and wild cherry, almost certainly used to replace the elms lost through Dutch elm disease. By Thicketts Road is a whitebeam plantation, and there is a large area of ash -planted by Dean Lane. On the northern edge of the sector studied there is an area of managed woodland, and this appears to be for pheasant rearing rather than for foorestry purposes. Stands of ash and beech, interspersed with conifers, soar above the old coppiced hazel which provides ground cover for the game.
